TURNER, Ohio DONALD NORCROSS, New Jersey MIKE COFFMAN, Colorado COLLEEN HANABUSA, Hawaii BRADLEY BYRNE, Alabama RO KHANNA, California SAM GRAVES, Missouri Tim Morrison, Counsel Leonor Tomero, Counsel Mike Gancio, Clerk </option>

Hearing.subcomitteeComposition: <subcomittee_name>Subcommittee on Strategic Forces............................... 1</subcomittee_name> <Witness>Hon Mike Rogers</Witness> <peopleinfo>a Representative from Alabama Chairman</peopleinfo> <witnesses>WITNESSES</witnesses> <Witness>LTG James H Dickinson</Witness> <peopleinfo>USA Commander</peopleinfo> <Witness>Thomas H (Todd) Harvey</Witness> <peopleinfo>Acting Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy Plans</peopleinfo> <Witness>Barry J Pike</Witness> <peopleinfo>Program Executive Officer Army Missiles and Space Syring</peopleinfo> <option>APPENDIX</option> <Speakers>Prepared Statements:</Speakers> <peopleSpeaker>Hon Jim Cooper</peopleSpeaker> <peopleinfo>a Representative from Tennessee Ranking Member</peopleinfo> <Doc-title>FISCAL YEAR 2018 PRIORITIES AND POSTURE OF MISSILE DEFEAT PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES</Doc-title> <option> ACTIVITIES ---------- House of Representatives, Committee on Armed Services, </option> <option>Subcommittee on Strategic Forces,</option> <option> Washington, DC, Wednesday, June 7, 2017. The subcommittee met, pursuant to call, at 2:57 p.m., in room 2212, Rayburn House Office Building, Hon. Mike Rogers (chairman of the subcommittee) presiding. </option>
Hearing.Statement: <opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. MIKE ROGERS, A REPRESENTATIVE FROM</opening> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="HON. MIKE ROGERS"> ALABAMA, CHAIRMAN, SUBCOMMITTEE ON STRATEGIC FORCES </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rogers</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Rogers">Good afternoon. I want to welcome everybody to our hearing this afternoon: ``Fiscal Year 2018 Priorities and Posture of Missile Defeat Programs and Activities.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Rogers">We have an esteemed group of witnesses with us today: Mr. Todd Harvey, Acting Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans, and Capabilities; Vice Admiral James Syring, U.S. Navy, Director of Missile Defense Agency; Lieutenant General James Dickinson, Commander, Joint Functional Component Command for Integrated Missile Defense, and Commander of U.S. Army Space and Missile Defense Command/Army Strategic Forces Command; and Mr. Barry Pike, who has the best accent on the panel, is Program Executive Officer, Army Missiles and Space.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Rogers">And before I get started, I want to take the chairman's prerogative for a minute. For almost 37 years, Vice Admiral Syring has served his country in uniform. Members of the subcommittee are most familiar with him as director of the Missile Defense Agency [MDA], which he has led since November of 2012.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Rogers">I remember the problems with the prior leadership of MDA and the devastating impact on its morale back in 2012. That has all changed under Admiral Syring's leadership. I think there is no better testament to his service and leadership than the recent Ground-Based Midcourse Defense system test against an ICBM [intercontinental ballistic missile] class target.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Rogers">With everything that is going on in the world, this success sends a powerful and unmistakable signal to allies and adversaries alike that we will defend ourselves from ballistic missile attack and the threat of attack.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Rogers">Admiral Syring, we thank you for your service and very much hope it is not complete yet.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Rogers"> Admiral Syring. Thank you, sir. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rogers</speaker>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Mr. Rogers can be found in the</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Mr. Rogers can be found in th"> With that, because we were called for votes, we are on a shorter timeline, so I am going to dispense with my opening statement and yield to my friend and colleague from Tennessee for any opening statement that he may have. Appendix on page 27.] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Cooper</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Cooper">Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Cooper">I would like to add my praise for Admiral Syring, for his wonderful career so far in the military. We hope it continues.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Cooper"> But I also want to ask unanimous consent to put my statement into the record so that we can get on with the hearing. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rogers</speaker>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Mr. Cooper can be found in the</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Mr. Cooper can be found in th"> Without objection, so ordered. Appendix on page 29.] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rogers</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Rogers">All right. What I would ask, so we will have time for questions and then also time to go into the classified session, is ask each witness to try to summarize their statement in 3 or 4 minutes, if they could. The full statement will be admitted to the record without objection.</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF THOMAS H. (TODD) HARVEY, ACTING ASSISTANT</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="THOMAS H. (TODD) HARVEY"> First, we will start with Mr. Todd Harvey. You are recognized for summary of your testimony. SECRETARY OF DEFENSE FOR STRATEGY, PLANS, AND CAPABILITIES, </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Harvey</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Harvey">Thank you, sir.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Harvey">Chairman Rogers, Ranking Member Cooper, members of the subcommittee, thank you for the opportunity to testify on priorities and posture of missile defeat programs and activities and the Defense Department's continuing efforts to sustain and modernize our homeland missile defense capabilities so that we remain ahead of the threat while providing effective, integrated, interoperable regional missile defense capability.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Harvey">The U.S. homeland is currently protected by the Ground- Based Midcourse Defense system, GMD system. Improving the capacity, reliability, effectiveness of the GMD system is one of our highest priorities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Harvey">The President's budget proposal for fiscal year 2018 would fund the Redesigned Kill Vehicle, Long Range Discrimination Radar, would help lay the groundwork for a new radar in Hawaii, would continue funding advanced discrimination sensor technology and space-based kill assessment programs, remain on track to complete deployment of remaining intercepters in Alaska by the end of this year to bring the total to 44.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Harvey">We are also moving forward with efforts to bolster our defenses against advanced cruise missiles. From a regional standpoint, the President's fiscal year 2018 budget request also continues the deployment of missile defenses tailored to threats in Europe, Middle East, Asia-Pacific region.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Harvey">In Europe, we are continuing to implement the European Phased Adaptive Approach, EPAA, and working in close collaboration with our NATO [North Atlantic Treaty Organization] allies to develop advanced network of sensors and interceptors.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Harvey">The President's budget request also supports the Aegis Ashore system that we will deploy in Poland in the 2018 timeframe. NATO allies have committed to spend more than $1 billion on NATO ballistic missile defense command and control, and many of our allies are improving their national BMD [ballistic missile defense] capabilities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Harvey">In Asia-Pacific, our force posture includes Aegis BMD- capable ships, along with Patriot batteries deployed in Japan and South Korea, and the recent deployment of THAAD [Terminal High Altitude Area Defense] to South Korea. We have also converted the THAAD battery deployment to Guam to permanent status in response to North Korean threats.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Harvey">We also maintain robust ballistic missile defense presence in the Middle East, including land- and sea-based assets deployed in defense of our forward-located forces and those of our allies and partners. This is in addition to our efforts to build the capacity to those counterparts that will contribute to their ability to defend themselves.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Harvey">We must continue to look ahead, which means ensuring that our investment strategy and priorities balance the needs of addressing the most dangerous threats we confront today while positioning ourselves to respond to emerging threats over the next decade.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Harvey">On January 27 of this year, the President directed the Secretary of Defense to initiate a new Ballistic Missile Defense Review [BMDR] to identify measures to strengthen missile defense capabilities in the face of rapidly growing missile threats.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Harvey">The BMDR will be informed by the administration determination to develop a state-of-the-art missile defense system to defend the homeland and our regional interests. We expect to complete the BMDR this fall, and it will complement the missile defeat report mandated by the fiscal year 2017 NDAA [National Defense Authorization Act].</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Harvey">The Department of Defense continues to develop, procure, and field missile defense systems to protect vital U.S. national security interests. We are determined to stay ahead of the adversaries' ballistic and cruise missile developments, seek capabilities to lower cost per intercept, and defeat emerging ballistic and cruise missile threats.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Mr. Harvey can be found in the</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Mr. Harvey can be found in th"> Thank you for the opportunity to appear before you today. Look forward to your questions. Appendix on page 30.] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rogers</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Rogers">I thank you.</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF VADM JAMES D. SYRING, USN, DIRECTOR, MISSILEDEFENSE AGENCY</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="VADM JAMES D. SYRING">The Chair now recognizes Admiral Syring.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="VADM JAMES D. SYRING"> Admiral Syring. Mr. Chairman, Ranking Member Cooper, thank you for the opportunity to appear today. Sir, I will submit my written statement for the record. In lieu of an opening statement, I request permission to play the video from the test last week. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rogers</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Rogers">We would love to see that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Rogers">[The video referred to is retained in the subcommittee files and can be viewed upon request.]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Rogers">Admiral Syring. And I will narrate as this goes, sir, since it is un-narrated, and give the committee an idea of what was accomplished last week.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Rogers">The test was conducted on the 30th of May out in the Pacific. Here is a blue-water chart that depicts the test construct. The ground-based interceptor [GBI] was fired from Vandenberg Air Force Base. It was tracked by a TPY-2 on Wake Island and the SBX [Sea-based X-band Radar] in the northwest Pacific, giving the interceptor solution to Vandenberg to intercept a target launched from the Kwajalein Atoll in the Marshall Islands.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Rogers">The red indicates the target fly-out, and the green indicates the GBI from Vandenberg.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Rogers">Here is a picture from the target lifting off from the Kwajalein Atoll in the Marshall Islands, 5,000 miles away from the coast of California. This is the longest range target that we have ever flown, the highest altitude, and the highest closing velocity for an intercept, and this intercept was done with countermeasures.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Rogers">Next, you will see a picture of the ground-based interceptor launch from Vandenberg Air Force Base out of a test silo that is completely production representative of the actual silos at Vandenberg, but this is what we test out of. The GBI is production representative of the CE-II Block 1s that will be fielded to fill out the 44 GBIs by the end of this calendar year.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Rogers">What you will see next is an onboard sensor view of the kill vehicle, which is separated from the GBI, and what the kill vehicle saw in space. This is actual live data from the test.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Rogers">What you see in red is the warhead from the target. And what you see in green is its tank that is flying alongside, because in space, everything flies at the same velocity. And you see the kill vehicle focused on the red warhead and eventually dropping out the other debris in the scene.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Rogers">What you see next is the kill vehicle in acquisition and terminal, and that is an actual picture of the reentry vehicle that was destructed beyond recognition.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Rogers">What you will see here is another infrared picture of the target booster and the target warhead with the booster of the GBI flying by literally a second before the kill vehicle killed the target warhead.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Rogers">We had four or five different sensors strewn across the Pacific to validate what you just saw. That was not a simulation. That was actual live data played back from the test.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Admiral Syring can be found in</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Admiral Syring can be found i"> With that, sir, I stand ready for your questions. the Appendix on page 43.] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rogers</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Rogers">Outstanding. Thank you very much.</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON, USA, COMMANDER, JOINT</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON">Lieutenant General Dickinson, you are recognized. FUNCTIONAL COMPONENT COMMAND FOR INTEGRATED MISSILE DEFENSE, AND COMMANDER, U.S. ARMY SPACE AND MISSILE DEFENSE COMMAND/ARMY</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON">General Dickinson. Chairman Rogers, Ranking Member Cooper, and other distinguished members of the subcommittee, thank you for your continued support of our soldiers, civilians, and their families.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON">This is my initial appearance before this subcommittee, and it is, indeed, an honor to testify before you today to discuss the importance of missile defense to our Nation, and the need to maintain these capabilities in the face of a threat, as we all know, that continues to grow in both capacity and capability.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON">Today, I want to briefly summarize the missions of the organizations I represent. First, Space and Missile Defense Command or SMDC, Army Forces Strategic Command, ARSTRAT, which serve as a force provider in support of our combatant commanders.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON">Our six lines of effort are to, number one, protect the homeland; provide combat-ready space and missile defense professionals; plan, synchronize, and integrate global operations; produce or adopt leap-ahead concepts and technologies; preserve and account for the Nation's critical resources; and promote and foster a positive command climate.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON">Our six lines of effort apply not only to the missile defense, but also to Army space. The Army has more than 4,000 military and civilian space cadre that provide continuous space-based capabilities and support to the warfighter from 22 different locations and 11 different time zones around the world.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON">Within SMDC ARSTRAT, our future warfare center and technical center develops space and missile defense concepts, requirements, and doctrine; provide training to the Army space cadre, and missile defense operators; and executes space and missile defense research and development.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON">I also represent the Joint Force Component Command for Integrated Missile Defense, or JFCC IMD, which supports U.S. Strategic Command [STRATCOM) in integrating and synchronizing our global missile defense operations.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON">For example, today, we have approximately 300 full-time National Guard soldiers located in Colorado Springs, Colorado; Fort Greely, Alaska; and Vandenberg Air Force Base, California, who operate the ground-based missile defense system.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON">It represents the Nation's only defense against intercontinental ballistic missile attack. These trained and fully certified missile defense professionals execute a strategically important mission 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year. They refer to themselves as 300 soldiers protecting the 300 million.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON">Additionally, in support of U.S. STRATCOM, JFCC IMD executes the following key tasks: Synchronizing operational level planning; supporting ongoing operations; integrating training exercises; test activities globally; providing recommendations on the allocation of low-density, high-demand missile defense resources; and advocating for future capabilities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON">As reported, the missile threat continues to grow, both in terms of numbers and sophistication. We as a Nation must maintain our current readiness posture and continue to increase our capabilities to address future threats.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON">Finally, I would like to highlight, the challenges we face today cannot be addressed without the dedication of our greatest asset: our people. Service members, civilians, contractors, and their families, those stationed at home, as well as those globally deployed provide support to the Army and joint warfighter each and every day.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="LTG JAMES H. DICKINSON">We remain committed to providing trained and ready soldiers, civilians to operate and pursue advancements in space and missile defense capabilities for the Nation. This committee's continued support of missile defense operations and the men and women who develop and deploy our systems is essential.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of General Dickinson can be found</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="General Dickinson can be foun"> Again, I appreciate the opportunity to discuss our Nation's missile defense capabilities, and I look forward to addressing your questions. Thank you. in the Appendix on page 73.] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rogers</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Rogers">Thank you.</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF BARRY J. PIKE, PROGRAM EXECUTIVE OFFICER, ARMYMISSILES AND SPACE</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="BARRY J. PIKE"> Mr. Pike, you are recognized. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Pike</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Pike">Thank you, sir.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Pike">Chairman Rogers, Ranking Member Cooper, and distinguished members of the subcommittee, I am honored to appear before you to testify on missile defense, and to thank you for your continued support of our people and our mission at Program Executive Office for Missiles and Space.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Pike">Support to our warfighters and their readiness remains our number one priority. I lead the materiel development, production, fielding, and sustainment support for assigned missile and space systems for the Army. This includes the centralized management of Army Air and Missile Defense, long- range precision fires, close combat, and aviation missile systems, as well as designated space programs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Pike">In today's complex, dynamic, and volatile security environment, Army Air and Missile Defense is a key strategic enabler. As such, our focus continues to be on providing warfighting solutions to the Army combatant commands and their national partners across the operational spectrum.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Pike">We accomplish this by working closely with other military departments, the Missile Defense Agency, the Army Space and Missile Defense Command, to support joint integrated air and missile defense capabilities.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Mr. Pike can be found in the</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Mr. Pike can be found in th"> Mr. Chairman, Ranking Member Cooper, and members of the subcommittee, I look forward to addressing your questions. Appendix on page 98.] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rogers</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Rogers">I thank all the witnesses for their statements, and I will recognize myself first for questions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Rogers">Admiral Syring, we have seen at least 78 ballistic missile tests by North Korea since Kim Jong-un came to power. More than 60 of these are assessed to be successes. It appears that he has had success with solid fuel ballistic missiles, including those launched by submarines and on the ground, and he may have recently shown that he can build a reentry vehicle and it can survive reentry.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Rogers">In an unclassified setting, I have to ask: Does this budget request allow us to remain paced comfortably ahead of the threat; and secondly, if we fully fund your request, and it remains at the same level of funding, less than $8 billion a year, of which increasing amounts are procurement and O&M [operations and maintenance], not research and development, will we continue to stay ahead of the threat, or is it moving faster than we are?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Rogers">Admiral Syring. Sir, with the work of this committee and others and the support of Congress, I would not say we are comfortably ahead of the threat. I would say we are addressing the threat that we know today. And the advancements in the last 6 months have caused great concern to me and others in the advancement of and demonstration of technology of ballistic missiles from North Korea.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Rogers"> It is incumbent upon us to assume that North Korea today can range the United States with an ICBM carrying a nuclear warhead. Everything that we are doing plans for that contingency, and in addition to looking ahead to what might be developed and what is possible over the next 5 to 10 years. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rogers</speaker> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Rogers">In an open setting, to the extent that you can, would you characterize what North Korea has been doing for the last 6 months?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Rogers"> Admiral Syring. They have been not only testing at an alarming rate in violation of international law, but demonstrating technology that feeds development of longer-range missiles and more capable missiles as well. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rogers</speaker> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Rogers">Can you discuss your timeline for developing and deploying the LRDR [Long Range Discrimination Radar]. How long will the MDA take to do that and from requirement finalization to deployment?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Rogers"> Admiral Syring. From the specific requirement of when LRDR was developed, it was back in 2014, and we were under contract in late 2015, if I get the timeline correct. And we will IOC [initial operating capability] it to the warfighter in late 2020. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rogers</speaker> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Rogers"> Okay. With that, I will yield to the ranking member for his opening questions. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Cooper</speaker> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Cooper">Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Cooper"> In view of the lateness of the hearing and the large number of subcommittee members who are here, I would defer my questions for the classified portion of the hearing. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rogers</speaker> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Rogers"> The Chair now recognizes the gentleman from Arizona, Mr. Franks, for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Franks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Franks">Well, thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Franks">And, Admiral Syring, everybody said it, but I just hope you know my name is on the list of those who honor and revere your commitment to this country and your service.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Franks"> Admiral Syring. It is my honor. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Franks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Franks">Admiral Syring, has MDA completed the inventory objective for both the SM-3 1B and the 2A?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Franks"> Admiral Syring. So there is not a stated inventory objective, but I know what the Navy is thinking it should be, and we are not close to that. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Franks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Franks">When do you think this objective or this--when do you think we could achieve that objective?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Franks"> Admiral Syring. At the production rate of--I will just--Mr. Franks, I will plan for 40 to 50 a year. It will be within the next 4 to 5 years. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Franks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Franks">You know, sometimes it is important for us to understand how much oversight MDA receives in the executive branch and legislative branches. Sometimes it is an enormous burden on you. But I would like to just ask you to detail how many meetings, how many RFIs [requests for information], and how much paperwork is involved at MDA for these oversight processes.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Franks"> Admiral Syring. Can I give you a qualitative answer? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Franks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Franks">Yes, sir.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Franks"> Admiral Syring. A lot. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Franks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Franks">A lot, yeah.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Franks"> Admiral Syring. Sir, we are under a tremendous amount of oversight, and answer many questions from many different organizations on the development of missile defense technology and capability. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Franks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Franks">Well, given that it is a lot, for all of this work, how many recommendations did GAO [Government Accountability Office] have in its fiscal year 2016 report?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Franks"> Admiral Syring. There were three or four if you parse one. I will say four for the record. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Franks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Franks">And how many of those were validated by DOD [Department of Defense]?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Franks"> Admiral Syring. We didn't agree with three of the four. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Franks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Franks">Three of the four. So how about the fiscal year 2015 report. I am not going to pursue this much longer.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Franks"> Admiral Syring. I don't recall any recommendations, specific recommendations from that report. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Franks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Franks">So how much oversight would MDA have if we made the BMDS [Ballistic Missile Defense System] accountability report and the GAO mandate biannual and alternated when they were submitted? And how could the agency better focus on the mission if we did that?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Franks">Admiral Syring. Sir, I want to just start by saying that, given the oversight responsibility, we have actually a constructive relationship with GAO. So I don't want to impugn GAO in any way. We work closely with them.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Franks"> But to answer your question directly, I think a biannual report would be more than sufficient in terms of their oversight responsibility. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Franks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Franks">Well, let me shift gears on you here. How long do you think it will be before the GMD system has operational spares to ensure we maintain 44 GBIs at all times?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Mr. Franks"> Admiral Syring. Sir, it will be post-2020 when we have a Redesigned Kill Vehicle [RKV] available for procurement. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Franks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Mr. Franks">And I know you need to pull GBIs from the ground for the RKV recapitalization of the CE-1 interceptors. Is that correct?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Mr. Franks"> Admiral Syring. That is correct, sir. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Franks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Mr. Franks">How can we ensure that we don't fall below that 44 GBIs emplaced in the calendar year 2018?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Mr. Franks">Admiral Syring. Sir, in fiscal year 2018, the Department made a downpayment on solving that problem with $150 million to go towards two silos and six boosters that would--two silos additionally up in Fort Greely.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Mr. Franks"> And there will be a tail to that in fiscal year 2019 and out to complete that work.
